CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--11      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  669900
Declaration of Amy Fly on Behalf of Ideare Bailey  
 
 
My name is Amy Fly. I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the state of Pennsylvania. 
On April 15, 2020, I spoke with Ideare Bailey (Bookin# 20014713), a detainee in the Dallas 
County Jail. He provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. Bailey is 35 years old and has type 2 diabetes. 
 
2.  He was booked into Dallas County Jail on April 6, 2020 for property theft. The judge 
granted him a bond reduction and ordered electronic monitoring as a condition of his 
release. Though his wife paid his bond on April 15, 2020, the jail will not release Mr. 
Bailey because the electronic monitoring company has been unable to provide him with a 
monitoring device.  
 
3.  When Mr. Bailey entered the jail on April 6, 2020, he was healthy. He and his wife had 
practiced social distancing for a month leading up to his arrest and he was not exhibiting 
any symptoms of the virus until he was exposed sick people inside the jail. 
 
4.  During intake, no one asked Mr. Bailey any questions related to COVID-19.  
 
5.  Mr. Bailey was placed in South Tower pod 2C with about 60 other people. The man who 
slept in the bunk directly next to Mr. Bailey was coughing, but was never tested for the 
virus.  
 
6.  Mr. Bailey developed a cough and went to the infirmary about 15 times over the course 
of the next 4 days. Each time, the nurse did not check his temperature and sent him back 
to the pod.  
 
7.  The first time anyone took Mr. Bailey’s temperature was Friday, April 10th, when he was 
running a fever of 106 degrees Fahrenheit. He was then transferred to the infirmary in the 
basement of the North Tower, where he is currently being held with about 15 other 
detainees who tested positive for the virus. To Mr. Bailey’s knowledge, the staff did not 
check the temperature of anyone else in pod 2C and Mr. Bailey was the only one 
removed from the pod.  
 
8.  Mr. Bailey was not tested for COVID-19 for two more days. On Monday, April 13, 2020, 
he was informed that he tested positive. The staff have not given Mr. Bailey any 
information about the virus, including how to prevent it from spreading.  
 
9.  Mr. Bailey was given a mask for the first time 3 days ago and has not been given any 
replacements. The staff make him wear the same mask all day. Some guards make him 
wear it when he sleeps; some do not.  
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--11      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  669911
10. Mr. Bailey is not receiving sufficient medical care. He is not given enough insulin to 
manage his blood sugar levels. He is not being properly monitored. If he had a medical 
emergency, he would have to bang on the window to get a nurse’s attention.  
 
11. Mr. Bailey cannot file a grievance because he does not have access to the kiosk, paper, or 
writing utensils. 
 
12. If Mr. Bailey were to be released, there is ample space in his home for him to isolate from 
his family for any required period of quarantine.  
 
 
I declare under the penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct. I have read this 
declaration to Mr. Bailey and he confirmed its accuracy.   
 
April 15, 2020           __/s/Amy Fly_____________________ 
York, PA              Amy Fly  
 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--22      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  11      PPaaggeeIIDD  669922
Second Declaration of Alison Grinter on behalf of Kiara Yarborough   
 
My name is Alison Grinter. I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the Eastern District of 
Texas. On April 17, 2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Kiara 
Yarborough (Bookin# 19060031) and she provided me with the following information: 
1.  Ms. Yarborough is 25 years old. She is detained in the Dallas County Jail in the South (Kays) 
Tower, 4D. She has been in the jail since December 19, 2019. 
 
2.  She said that the inmates all got masks on the 10th but they only gave each person one. Since 
then, hers got clogged and gross and won’t let any air in. She says she’s scared to sleep 
without it but doesn’t even see how it’s helping anymore.  
 
 
3.  The pod across the hall from hers got quarantined yesterday. Today the guards pulled two 
inmates from her pod to go clean the pod that was emptied out because the inmates went into 
COVID quarantine. 
 
4.  She believes her pod is at 63 or completely full to the 64 person capacity because they keep 
bringing people in from other towers as the virus count keeps climbing. 
 
 
5.  She reported that the food has continued to deteriorate. Today, they had peanut butter and 
jelly sandwiches for lunch. She hears that’s because the kitchen officers and inmate trustees 
are in quarantine. The pod has had the same thing for dinner, sort of a leftover stew that the 
inmates call goulash, for a week straight. 
 
6.  She reports that she has a bacterial vaginosis infection that in the past tends to spread to her 
kidneys and develop into pyelonephritis and she is on antibiotics right now. She’s worried 
that it will spread to her kidneys and make her more vulnerable if she gets COVID-19. 
 
 
7.  She said “I know that we don’t get treated like princesses here in jail but I want to leave out 
of here alive.” 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 17, 2020           _________________________ 
Dallas County           Alison Grinter

1.  Ms. Washington is 26 years old. She previously made a declaration in this case (on April

2.  Last Wednesday or Thursday, the Pod was given masks, paper disposable masks. One

3.  They make us wear them to talk to the guards but they’re not mandatory in the dayroom

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--44      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  44      PPaaggeeIIDD  669955
 
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Oscar Sanchez  
 
My name is Amy Fly I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the state of Pennsylvania. I 
spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Oscar Sanchez (Bookin# 20011561) several 
times from April 3-7, 2020. Mr. Sanchez provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. Sanchez is 28 years old. He has been detained in five different locations within the 
Dallas County Jail since his incarceration began on March 9, 2020. He was transferred 
between the following units in this order: the 4th floor of the West Tower, E pod on the 
3rd floor of the South Tower, H pod on the 1st floor of South Tower, a holding tank 
(where he was housed for 3 days with 6 other detainees waiting for new placement), and 
C pod of the 3rd floor of the South Tower (where he is currently detained as of the date of 
this declaration).  
 
2.  Each pod in the South Tower has 64 beds in one room and holds about 58-60 people at 
any given time. The beds are about 3-4 feet apart from each other. 
 
3.  Mr. Sanchez was moved to H pod on the 1st floor of South Tower after there were 
confirmed positive cases of COVID-19 in E pod. One man who tested positive spent 3-4 
days vomiting before he was removed from the dorm. When the jailers escorted him out 
of the dorm, they gave a detainee in E pod a biohazard bag and made him collect the sick 
man’s belongings. The detainee was not given any protective gear when he cleaned the 
sick man’s bunk and he continued living in dorm E and interacting with Mr. Sanchez and 
the other 60 men in the pod. When more and more people in dorm E tested positive for 
the virus, the jailers split everyone in the dorm up and moved them to different pods. 
They did not check anyone’s temperature before moving detainees into new dorms. Mr. 
Sanchez was moved to the first floor of H pod, which had more people than E pod. 
Without explanation, Mr. Sanchez was moved back to the third floor of South Tower. He 
does not know whether the area was disinfected before he returned.  
 
4.  Mr. Sanchez has a history of chronic asthma that has been so severe that he was 
hospitalized. On April 5, 2020, he told a doctor he hard chest pains and difficulty 
breathing, and requested medical attention. The doctor told him there was nothing he 
could do about it because there was nothing in his file saying he is asthmatic. Before the 
pandemic, every time Mr. Sanchez told staff he was having respiratory problems, they 
would give him an emergency inhaler and then give him another inhaler when he saw a 
doctor. Now, Mr. Sanchez cannot get an inhaler unless he files a sick call and pays to be 
evaluated by a doctor.  
 
5.  When Mr. Sanchez asked guards for a facemask, he was told the only people that need 
masks are the guards. Some guards wear gloves and facemasks, but some do not. The 
guards that wear facemasks do not change their masks when they go from dorm to dorm.  
 
6.  All 60 men in both A and E pods must wear the same clothes 6 days in a row before they 
are given clean clothing.  
 
1 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--44      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  44      PPaaggeeIIDD  669966
 
7.  All 60 men in both A and E pods share 8 phones, none of which are disinfected between 
use.  
 
8.  All 60 men in both A and E pods share 6 showers, and 8 toilets. The entire dorm, 
including the showers and the toilets, are cleaned by three detainees who volunteer to 
clean for special privileges, like an additional tray of food. Mr. Sanchez started 
volunteering because his bunk is 3 feet from the toilets and the other volunteers usually 
do not clean properly.  
 
9.  All 60 men in both A and E pods eat meals together in the day room. There are not 
enough tables, so it is impossible for everyone to sit without touching the people sitting 
on either side of them. Many detainees even drink out of the same cup.  
 
10. Several times a day, all the men in Mr. Sanchez’s dorm line up back to back to receive 
meals and medication. The men are no more than one foot apart. The same protocol is 
followed to receive clean clothes and commissary whenever it is delivered. The person 
distributing medication wears the same masks and gloves in every dorm. The person 
distributing food usually does not wear a masks at all. 
 
11. On March 26, the jail no longer allowed detainees to purchase all items, including soap, 
from the commissary. The jail does not provide nearly enough soap to last the week.  
 
 
12. On March 30, Mr. Sanchez started noticing the food portions getting smaller. There also 
seemed to be a shortage of blankets and clothes.  
 
13. Recently Mr. Sanchez noticed more and more staff disappear from the jail. The jail has 
become so short staffed, they are now training people who worked in the kitchen and 
laundry room to be in the dorms.  
 
14. Typically there are about 6-7 new people introduced to Mr. Sanchez’s dorm each week 
and 6-7 people transferred to a different dorm or released. This has not changed since the 
start of the pandemic. The newest detainees arrived as recently as April 2nd and 3rd. 
 
15. On April 6, 2020, Mr. Sanchez asked the nurse on second shift if she could check his 
temperature because he felt feverish, and had a sore throat and cough, body chills, and a 
throbbing headache. The nurse responded that fever and sore throat are not symptoms of 
the coronavirus and he should stop worrying.  
 
16. About 30 minutes later, the same nurse entered Mr. Sanchez’s dorm and made an 
announcement that they could avoid catching the virus by washing their hands, avoiding 
groups of 10 or more, not touching their face, and covering their mouths. She also put up 
a poster saying the same. This was the first time the jail told Mr. Sanchez anything about 
how to prevent the spread of the virus. When Mr. Sanchez asked how they avoid groups 
of 10 when they live in a group of 60, and how to wash their hands without soap, the 
2 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--44      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  44  ooff  44      PPaaggeeIIDD  669977
 
nurse replied “I’m not here to have a debate. Don’t worry, you don’t have the virus” The 
next day, the same nurse made an announcement that 25% of people who have the virus 
don’t show symptoms and don’t even know they have it. When Mr. Sanchez tried to ask 
how they know no one in pod has the virus, she cut him off and said “I’m not here to 
answer questions.”  
 
17. On April 7, 2020, Mr. Sanchez’s symptoms got worse and he explicitly asked to be tested 
for the coronavirus. The guard told him he informed his superiors that Mr. Sanchez was 
really sick and using the phones everyone else uses, so he needed to be tested. His 
supervisor responded that Mr. Sanchez could not be tested unless he put in a sick call, 
which costs $10. The guard relaying this information to Mr. Sanchez said “I don’t know 
what these people want you to do. Die first?” As of the date of this declaration, Mr. 
Sanchez has not been tested for the virus.  
 
 
18. Mr. Sanchez was repeatedly denied grievance forms every time he requested them. On 
April 5, 2020, Mr. Sanchez filed an emergency grievance stating that he fears for his life 
under current conditions. Afterwards, a jailer told Mr. Sanchez he was being watched and 
warned him not to do anything outside of the rule book because other jailers are looking 
for an opportunity to retaliate against him. On April 6, 2020, Mr. Sanchez had not 
received a response to his emergency grievance, so he file an appeal. A jailer then came 
into his dorm, laughed at the detainees in the pod, and said “You think filing grievances 
is going to change anything?” The following morning, Mr. Sanchez tried using the kiosk 
to check the status of this grievance and appeal, but the application to file grievances and 
check their status was removed from the kiosk. 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 7, 2020                        _____s/ Amy Fly_______________ 
Dallas County                            Amy Fly

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--55      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  669999
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Marcus White  
 
My name is Amy Fly I am an attorney who is licensed to practice law in the state of 
Pennsylvania. I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Marcus White (Bookin# 
19056720) on April 4th and 5th of 2020. Mr. White provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. White is 37 years old. He is incarcerated on an $111,000 bond that he cannot afford 
to pay. On April 4, 2020 was informed that he tested positive for COVID-19. 
 
2.  When Mr. White first arrived at the jail, he was detained in South Tower where 5 people 
were known to have tested positive for COVID-19. Around March 21st, Mr. White started 
showing symptoms of the virus, including coughing, congestion, body aches, and 
diarrhea. He continued interacting with other people in his 60-man dorm for four more 
days. On March 25th, he was moved to a single cell in dorm 7 on the 9th Floor of West 
Tower, where he is confined to his cell 24 hours a day. There, the staff checked his 
temperature daily, but did not test him for the virus until April 2nd.  
 
3.  The guards that moved Mr. White from South Tower to West Tower wore masks and 
suits, but detainees are not provided with any personal protective equipment.  
 
4.  The jail staff never told Mr. White about how to avoid spreading the virus. While in 
South Tower, he learned on the news that the virus is airborne and can stay on surfaces 
for several days. Mr. White no longer has access to the news in West Tower.  
 
5.  Mr. White suffers from grand mal seizures, which cause his him to lose consciousness 
and have violent muscle contractions. His seizures are often stress induced and require 
daily medication. He also takes daily medication for hypertension. Though the staff has 
given him access to his blood pressure medication, they are not giving him seizure 
medication.  
 
6.  As of the date of this declaration, Mr. White had not received any soap or cleaning 
supplies since he was moved to West Tower on March 25.  
 
7.  As of the date of this declaration, Mr. White has not received any clean laundry and 
continues to use to the same clothes and bed linen he had when he was in the South 
Tower. 
 
8.  Mr. White was denied a shower for a week.  
 
9.  Mr. White and four other men detained on the 9th floor of West Tower were denied 
grievance forms despite numerous requests. Mr. White made a sign demanding grievance 
forms and hung it on his cell. For a week, the men banged on their cell doors and refused 
to allow the nurses take their temperatures until they were given grievance forms. On

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--66      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  770022
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Tesmond McDonald    
 
My name is Amy Fly and I am licensed to practice law in the State of Pennsylvania. On April 6, 
2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Tesmond McDonald (Bookin# 
19047475) and he provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. McDonald is 32 years old. On April 3, 2020, he found out he tested positive for 
COVID-19.  
 
2.  Mr. McDonald has asthma and high blood, which he takes medication for.  
 
3.  The jail failed to give him adequate access to an asthma pump on several occasions. 
When he first arrived at the jail, he waited two weeks to be given his asthma pump. Refill 
request also took days. 
 
4.  Mr. developed body aches and began having trouble catching his breath. He started over-
using his asthma pump in order to compensate, which made him jittery. He knew 
something was wrong. The nurse took his oxygen levels, which were dangerously low – 
59 or 60 mm Hg. He was sent to the infirmary and given a new asthma pump. He did not 
have one at the time because he used up his old pump and the jail had not yet responded 
to his request for a new one. A week later, he was tested positive for COVID-19.  
 
5.  On one occasion, Mr. McDonald asked to go to a doctor because he could not breathe – 
he thought he was going to die. They told him they can’t do anything about it and that he 
needed to wait until tomorrow. Even then, he still never saw a doctor.  
 
6.  Someone comes around and takes his temperature and heart rate every day. He has a sore 
throat and diarrhea, but the jailers have not given him any medication for these 
symptoms. They are not even giving him enough water to stay hydrated.  
 
7.  When Mr. McDonald first arrived at the jail, he was places in South Tower 3A. When 
four people in his dorm tested positive for COVID-19, he was moved to the West Tower 
and placed on lock down in a single cell.  
 
8.  When Mr. McDonald first arrived at West Tower, it took him a week to get clean clothes.  
 
9.  The walls in his cell are so dirty that he is afraid to touch them.  
 
10. Once a week, he and the other detainees in his dorm are given three pieces of soap 1/4th 
the size of a state ID. They are completely used up in one use. He does not have access to 
commissary to buy more soap.  
 
11. He is only allowed to shower once a week, so he takes bird bathes in the sink. At one 
point, he was denied a shower for 10 days.

Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Marcelo Perez  
 
My name is Amy Fly I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the state of Pennsylvania. I 
spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Marcelo Perez (Bookin# 20001013) on April 
7-8, 2020. Mr. Perez provided me with the following information:  
   
 
1.  Mr. Perez is 43 years old. He has been in the jail since January 7, 2020 because of 
drug charges and probation violations.  
 
2.  He has high blood pressure and is diabetic. When he first arrived at the jail, a nurse 
checked his sugar levels twice a day and gave him varying doses of metformin 
depending on his sugar levels. Now, the nurse doesn’t check his sugar levels at all 
and gives him a set dosage twice a day. The dose is often too high and keeps him 
awake all night.  
 
3.  Mr. Perez used to be detained on the second floor of South Tower in pod H. This pod 
held about 60 men, some of which were exhibiting clear signs of COVID-19. At least 
2 or 3 of the men were coughing for several weeks. They were so sick that Mr. Perez 
told the nurse they needed to be checked out, but they were never evaluated and did 
not receive any medical treatment.  
 
4.  On March 22, 2020, Mr. Perez and two other detainees were moved to C pod on the 
3rd floor as punishment for inappropriate laughter. No one took their temperatures or 
tested them for the virus before moving them. A week later, Mr. Perez developed a 
cough. He has still not been tested for the virus, though his cough has since subsided.   
 
5.  Detainees must pay $10 in order to be seen by a nurse. After payment is made, the 
detainee is not seen by the nurse for 2-3 weeks. Mr. Perez cannot make requests to 
see a nurse because he does not have any money on his account.  
 
6.  Mr. Perez has never seen a detainee wearing a mask. When Mr. Perez asked for a 
mask, he was told that the jail staff have to buy their own masks, so they would not 
give him one. Some detainees tried wrapping bath towels around their heads to cover 
their faces, but the jail staff told them they were not allowed to do that.  
 
7.  Mr. Perez has seen only one out of every six guards wearing masks. The guards are 
not practicing social distancing. He has seen them close together in large groups, and 
watched multiple guards share from a single bag of chips.  
 
8.  Mr. Perez filed an emergency grievance on April 6, 2020. He has not received a 
response.  On April 7, 2020, he attempted to check the status of his emergency 
grievance on the kiosk, but the staff removed the grievance portal from the kiosk.  
 
1 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--77      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  770066
9.  Mr. Perez is in the same pod as Oscar Sanchez. On April 8, 2020, the jail staff called 
for Mr. Sanchez to go to the nurse’s station. He never returned. The guards then made 
his cellie, Fernando, clean Mr. Sanchez’s bunk and collect his belongings. They did 
not give Mr. Fernando any personal protective equipment before he followed this 
order.  
 
 
 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 8, 2020                        _____s/ Amy Fly_______________ 
Dallas County               Amy Fly  
 
  
2

Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Roger Morrison 
   

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--88      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  770088
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Roger Morrison 
 
 
My name is Amy Fly and I am licensed to practice law in the state of Pennsylvania. On April 8, 
2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Roger Morrison (Bookin# 20011453) 
and he provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. Morrison is 49 years old. He was admitted to the jail on March 9, 2020 for drug 
possession charges. Mr. Morrison has never been convicted of or charged with a violent 
offense.  
 
2.  Mr. Morrison is in the medical pod (South Tower, C3) because he suffers from severe 
allergies, high blood pressure, hepatitis C, and cirrhosis of the liver. Because of these 
ailments, he has a weak immune system. He takes several medications daily, including a 
pill for nerve pain stemming from the 12 screws in his back.  
 
3.  The staff have not told Mr. Morrison anything about COVID-19. He knows he is high 
risk, but does not know how to prevent himself from getting the virus. He cannot tell 
from looking at someone whether they have the virus. Some people in his pod look sick, 
but he does not know what they are sick with. He does not want to sit in jail and die.  
 
4.  Social distancing in the pod is impossible. They are packed in there like sardines. His bed 
is one foot from another bunk on one side and three feet from another bunk on the other 
side.  
 
5.  The guards sometimes wear masks, but sometimes they don’t. Detainees are not allowed 
to have masks.  
 
6.  The pod is filthy, and the detainees only have occasional access to hand soap.  
 
7.  Recently, Mr. Morrison has started sneezing and feeling nauseous.  
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 8, 2020                        _____s/ Amy Fly_______________ 
Dallas County               Amy Fly  
 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--99      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  770099
 
Exhibit 6 
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Keith Baker 
   

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--99      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  771100
Declaration of Amy Fly on behalf of Keith Baker  
 
My name is Amy Fly and I am licensed to practice law in Pennsylvania.  On April 4, 2020, I 
spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Keith Baker (Bookin#20011122) and he 
provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. Baker is 25 years old and is currently detained on the 9th floor of the West Tower in 
Tank #1 with 4 other detainees. Mr. Baker and the other men in Tank #1 have made 
several requests to be moved because they do not have COVID-19, but are held next to 
people who have tested positive for the virus. Tank #2, which is directly connected to Mr. 
Baker, holds three people who have tested positive.  
 
2.  Mr. Baker has severe asthma and used an inhaler on a regular basis before his detention 
at the jail. Around 9am on March 26, 2020 Mr. Baker suffered a severe asthma attack. A 
sergeant and two officers observed him unable to catch his breath and walked away 
without saying anything. The doctor came to his cell five and a half hours later. All he 
did was gave Mr. Baker a sleeping pill.  
 
3.  Mr. Baker was also denied medical treatment for a dislocated shoulder and headaches. He 
only received ibuprofen after 4 days of complaining of pain.  
 
4.  When Mr. Baker first arrived at the jail, he was originally detained in the South Tower. 
After five inmates and one guard from his pod tested positive for the virus, the jail moved 
Mr. Baker to a single cell in the West Tower without testing him first. While at the West 
Tower, Keith developed a sore throat and a cough and all they did was take his 
temperature. He has not been tested for the virus. As of the date of this declaration, he is 
still being held in the same Wing as people who tested positive.  
 
 
5.  Though Mr. Baker is in a cell by himself, he is not isolated. His cell is connected to two 
other cells and he is still has contact with other detainees. As one example, he has had to 
borrow toiletries, such as toothpaste, from those in the cells around him because the jail 
stopped allowing commissary purchases on March 26, 2020.  
 
6.  The jail provides detainees with 4 single use bars of soap and tissues once a week on 
Staurday, but it is not even enough for one day. The only other way detainees can get 
additional soap is to purchase it through commissary, they no longer have access to. As a 
result, Mr. Baker must go six days a week without any soap at all.  
 
7.  When Mr. Baker first arrived in West Tower, he was required to eat his meals in his cell. 
The jailers served him food by smashing the food and shoving it in the crack between the 
door and the ground. He lost a significant amount of weight because of the small portions 
and poor quality of food. Since April 4, Mr. Baker and the other 4 people in his tank eat 
lunch together in the day room.  Of the 12 tanks on the 9th floor, the people in Mr. 
Baker’s tank are the only detainees permitted to use the day room.  

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--99      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  771111
 
8.  Those on the 9th Floor of the West Tower do not have access to clean clothes. At one 
point, Mr. Baker was forced to wear the same jumpsuit every day for ten days straight. 
He was also not permitted to take a shower during that 10 day period. When he was 
finally allowed to take a shower, the water was cold.  
 
9.  Mr. Baker was provided with a mask only after he asked for one. He has had to use the 
same one repeatedly because he was not given replacements. The staff in the West Tower 
wear masks, but they do not change them out between interactions with detainees who 
have the virus and those who don’t have the virus.  
 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 4, 2020              _/s/ Amy Fly__________________ 
Dallas County             Amy Fly

Declaration of Adwoa Asante on behalf of Paul Wright 
   

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1100      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  771133
Declaration of Adwoa Asante on behalf of Paul Wright  
 
My name is Adwoa Asante. I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the state of Texas. On 
April 7, 2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Paul Wright (Bookin# 
20008591) and he provided me with the following information:  
 
 
1.  Mr. Wright will be 48 years old on April 11, 2020.  He is located in South Tower on the 
3rd floor in Pod C. He is awaiting transfer to the Texas Department of Corrections (TDC) 
for a two-year sentence. He has credit for 14 months of his time in county jail and would 
be eligible for parole and release if not for COVID-19 obstructing TDC pickups from the 
county jail. 
 
2.  Mr. Wright has Hepatitis C and a bad knee but no known other health conditions. 
 
3.  Mr. Wright heard a new guard was exposed to three detainees in a different pod who 
were confirmed to have COVID-19. She does wear a mask, but she engages in normal 
activities which requires her to interact with detainees. She touches surfaces and during 
breaks she takes her mask off and touches her face. The detainees she interacts with, 
including Mr. Wright, do not have any protective gear. 
 
4.  No one in Mr. Wright’s dorm has been tested for the virus.  
 
5.  Detainees can only see a nurse if they submit a sick call kite. Then it takes several days 
for the nurse to see them. They are also charged $10 for each visit to the nurse. 
 
6.  It is impossible to engage in social distancing. There are about 60 people in the dorm and 
the bunk beds are about 3 feet away. There are 3 toilets, 2 urinals, and 5 showers that all 
60 people in the dorm have to share. They are cleaned about once a day and not after 
every use. 
 
7.  There are 5 regular phones and a video conference phone. Everyone in the tank shares 
them. They are not cleaned unless the detainees clean them themselves. They are 
supposed to be cleaned every shift change and it is usually a very brief cleaning. 
Sometimes it is not cleaned at all.  
 
8.  Sometimes the dorm gets a lot of soap, but sometimes they get none. They have to 
request more soap from the guards and they are sometimes denied. Sometimes the guards 
just don’t have the soap and other cleaning agents.  
 
9.  The jail staff have not provided Mr. Wright with information about the virus and how to 
prevent its spread. The only source of information on the virus is through the news.  
 
10. It is incredibly difficult to file grievances and appeals because they do not have any 
paper, so they have to get the guards to print out the forms or give them something to 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1100      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  771144
write on. Sometimes the guards simply will not do it. The guards are not interested in 
getting them the papers to file the grievances. 
 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 7, 2020            /s/ Adwoa Asante____ 
Dallas County             Adwoa Asante  

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1111      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  771155

Declaration of Alison Grinter on behalf of Terry 
McNickles 
   

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1111      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  771166
Declaration of Alison Grinter on behalf of Terry McNickles  
 
My name is Alison Grinter. I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the Eastern District of 
Texas. On April 7, 2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Terry McNickles 
(Bookin# 20012558) and he provided me with the following information:  
 
1.  Mr. McNickles, 58 years old, is an inmate in the Dallas County Jail, being held on a 
parole violation in the South tower, 3rd floor. His pod holds 64 beds and there are maybe 
48 or 49 men there as of the date of this declaration.  
 
2.  His pod is the medical section. He had an operation for kidney cancer last year and has 
only one kidney. When they took out his kidney, the doctor said he would have to keep a 
special diet and make sure to wash his hands a lot because it would be very hard for him 
to fight off infections. He also takes medication for high blood pressure.  
 
3.  He does absolutely everything he can. He washes his hands constantly but he is very 
afraid. 
 
4.  Nobody in his pod is practicing social distancing, including the detention service officers. 
Sometimes they have masks on, sometimes they don’t. The only person who consistently 
wears a mask is the nurse when she passes out medicine to people in the pill line.   
 
5.  Everyone is bunched together in the pod. Even if a person did try to practice social 
distancing, when you sleep, it’s just three feet from the nearest person. When the inmates 
get their trays to eat and when they get medicine, they are packed in close. 
 
6.  Mr. McNickles is in bunk 42. The man in bunk 40 was coughing and sent to the hospital. 
The jail staff said that the man had heart trouble. But he was clearly sick because he was 
coughing. 
 
7.  Mr. McNickels has asked for instructions on how to stay safe. He also asked for face 
masks. The jail staff haven’t told him or given him any personal protective gear. 
 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 7, 2020              _________________________ 
Dallas County             Alison Grinter  
 
1

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1122      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  22      PPaaggeeIIDD  771188
Declaration of Adwoa Asante on behalf of Jose Munoz  
 
My name is Adwoa Asante. I am an attorney who is licensed to practice in the state of Texas. On 
April 7, 2020, I spoke to a detainee in the Dallas County Jail named Jose Munoz (Bookin# 
19048523) and he provided me with the following information:  
 
 
1.  Mr. Jose Munoz is 37 years old. He is in jail for a drug possession charge, which he 
already pled guilty to and received 5 years of probation. He is currently waiting to go to a 
drug treatment facility, but is stuck in limbo because the facility is not picking up any 
detainees from the Dallas County Jail during the pandemic.  
 
2.  He has been in jail for six months and is currently located in South Tower 3C.  
 
3.  The guards are supposed to give the detainees personal protective equipment, but they 
have not received any masks or gloves.   
 
4.  Mr. Munoz has learned about the virus from the news, not from the jail staff. The guards 
sometimes they cover their mouths, but they generally pretend like nothing is going on. 
 
5.  There are 7 phones and 1 video conference booth that is shared amongst the entire dorm. 
The phones are cleaned every day by the detainees for their safety but not after every use. 
They use the chemicals for the restroom and for the tables. 
 
6.  They detainees are given soap irregularly and upon request. Mr. Munoz requested soap 
today and was told that the detainees were using excessive soap. He did not want to argue 
with the guards, so he did not receive any soap.  
 
7.  They are unable to engage in social distancing because of the climate and the structure of 
the jail. Mr. Munoz says that he cannot ask someone to move if they’re so close to him 
because he might be accused of being racist and this could lead to a physical altercation. 
He is very concerned about enforcing social distancing given the propensity for violence 
in the jail. 
 
8.  It is impossible to sleep 6 feet apart from each other because of the location of the bunks. 
 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the forgoing is true and correct.  
 
April 7, 2020                       /s/ Adwoa Asante_ 
Dallas County             Adwoa Asante

Exhibit 10 
             Amended Declaration of Alison Grinter 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1133      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  1133      PPaaggeeIIDD  772200
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
DALLAS DIVISION 
Oscar Sanchez, Marcus White, Tesmond  Civil Action No. 20-cv-832 
McDonald, Marcelo Perez, Roger Morrison, 
Keith Baker, Paul Wright, Terry McNickels, 
and Jose Munoz; on their own and on behalf 
of a class of similarly situated persons; 
Petitioners/Plaintiffs, 
v. 
DALLAS COUNTY SHERIFF MARIAN 
BROWN, in her official capacity; DALLAS 
COUNTY, TEXAS; 
Respondents/Defendants 
AMENDED DECLARATION OF ALISON GRINTER 
I, ALISON GRINTER, DECLARE: 
1. I am an attorney practicing almost exclusively criminal defense in the Dallas and
Collin County Courts. I am Board Certified in Criminal Law.  I serve as counsel for the plaintiffs 
and the putative class herein. 
2. I make this declaration of my personal knowledge.
3. Prior to the COVID-19 outbreak, an individual pretrial habeas petition seeking
consideration of bond by a District Judge in Dallas County would, under normal circumstances, 
heard and decided within a day or two. 
4. Even after the COVID-19 outbreak, these bond hearings are given priority by
Courts and are held as expeditiously as possible given restraints on staffing, and with consent of 
the parties, many are done informally or via email or telephone. 
5. An interlocutory appeal of a decision unfavorable to the defendant would likely
take months even before the courts were slowed due to the pandemic, but a decision from a 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1133      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  1133      PPaaggeeIIDD  772211
Dallas County District Judge would not be the source of that delay, rather the normal delays built 
into the appellate process. 
6.  Pre-trial writs alleging that a person is being restrained of their liberties in any 
way other than lack of reasonable bond set by a District Judge (for instance unconstitutional jail 
conditions) would take a distinct and presumably longer timeline, as they are not at all common 
in the State criminal district courts and presumably would require time for a prosecutor to brief. 
7.  Post-conviction writs would follow a different timeline with deliberative 
processes of many months before the COVID-19 outbreak.  
8.  Texas Courts, including those in Dallas, are issuing emergency closures and 
slowing their operations in response to the COVID-19 pandemic.  
9.  I am not aware of any avenue in the state courts through which a class of both 
pre- and post-adjudication detainees could seek relief regarding the constitutionality of their 
confinement in the Dallas County Jail. 
10.  Attached hereto as Exhibit A is a true and correct copy of an email from K. 
Dickerson, Criminal District Courts Manager, March 24, 2020, re:  Dallas County Criminal 
District Courts. 
11.  Attached hereto as Exhibit B is a true and correct copy of an email from K. 
Dickerson, Criminal District Courts Manager, March 19, 2020, re: Criminal District Court 1 
COVID-19 Protocol  
12.  Attached hereto as Exhibit C is an email from K. Dickerson, Criminal District 
Courts Manager, March 17, 2020, re: CDC 2 COVID-19 Protocol. 
13.  Attached hereto as Exhibit D is an email from K. Dickerson, Criminal District 
Courts Manager, March 16, 2020, re: CDC 5 COVID-19 Protocol. 
14.  As a criminal defense attorney practicing in Dallas County I received similar 
emails regarding COVID-19 protocols in many of the other Criminal District Courts. 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3399--1133      FFiilleedd  0044//1177//2200        PPaaggee  44  ooff  1133      PPaaggeeIIDD  772222
15.  Many of the Criminal District Courts have not adopted any specific written 
policies, but all have slowed or suspended functions. Policies and available services are often 
fluid and change daily depending on Court and staff availability. 
16.  As court staff have become exposed or have contracted the COVID-19, several 
courts have closed all or parts of the court operations for quarantine purposes. 
17.  I made a declaration on April 9th 2020 in this cause which stated, in relevant part: 
“Prior to the COVID-19 outbreak, an individual petitioner seeking habeas relief in the 
Texas State Courts could expect his or her petition to remain pending for months, 
particularly if an appeal were taken.” 
18.  The drafting of this sentence was inartful in a way that might be misleading, and I 
want to clarify it in advance of any Court proceeding. It was a sentence given to me in proposed 
language, and I read it to be commenting on the duration of a habeas petition that was in fact 
appealed after a decision unfavorable to the defendant. 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct.   
Executed this 15th day of April, 2020. 
 
                       
                                                Alison Grinter 
 
Alison Grinter 
Texas Bar Number 24043476 
6738 Old Settlers Way 
Dallas, Texas 75236 
(214) 704-6400 
alisongrinter@gmail.com 
agrinter@thengan.com

Dickerson, Criminal District Courts Manager, March 19, 2020, re: Criminal District Court 1 
COVID-19 Protocol  
12.  Attached hereto as Exhibit C is an email from K. Dickerson, Criminal District 
Courts Manager, March 17, 2020, re: CDC 2 COVID-19 Protocol. 
13.  Attached hereto as Exhibit D is an email from K. Dickerson, Criminal District 
Courts Manager, March 16, 2020, re: CDC 5 COVID-19 Protocol. 
14.  As a criminal defense attorney practicing in Dallas County I received similar 
emails regarding COVID-19 protocols in many of the other Criminal District Courts. 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3377      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  33      PPaaggeeIIDD  557722
15.  Many of the Criminal District Courts have not adopted any specific written 
policies, but all have slowed or suspended functions. Policies and available services are often 
fluid and change daily depending on Court and staff availability. 
16.  As court staff have become exposed or have contracted the COVID-19, several 
courts have closed all or parts of the court operations for quarantine purposes. 
17.  I made a declaration on April 9th 2020 in this cause which stated, in relevant part: 
“Prior to the COVID-19 outbreak, an individual petitioner seeking habeas relief in the 
Texas State Courts could expect his or her petition to remain pending for months, 
particularly if an appeal were taken.” 
18.  The drafting of this sentence was inartful in a way that might be misleading, and I 
want to clarify it in advance of any Court proceeding. It was a sentence given to me in proposed 
language, and I read it to be commenting on the duration of a habeas petition that was in fact 
appealed after a decision unfavorable to the defendant. 
 
I declare under penalty of perjury that the foregoing is true and correct.   
Executed this 15th day of April, 2020. 
 
                       
                                                Alison Grinter 
 
Alison Grinter 
Texas Bar Number 24043476 
6738 Old Settlers Way 
Dallas, Texas 75236 
(214) 704-6400 
alisongrinter@gmail.com 
agrinter@thengan.com

documents.title: Brief in Support of Defendant's Motion to Dismiss
documents.text:
CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554433
 
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
DALLAS DIVISION 
 
OSCAR SANCHEZ, MARCUS  § 
WHITE, TESMOND MCDONALD,  § 
MARCELO PEREZ, ROGER  § 
MORRISON, KEITH BAKER, PAUL  § 
WRIGHT, TERRY MCNICKLES,  § 
AND JOSE MUNOZ, on their own  § 
behalf and on behalf of a class of  §  Civil Action 
similarly situated persons,  §  Case No. 3:20-cv-00832 
  Petitioners/Plaintiffs,  § 
    § 
v.    § 
    § 
DALLAS COUNTY SHERIFF  § 
MARIAN BROWN, in Her Official  § 
Capacity; DALLAS COUNTY,  § 
TEXAS,  § 
  Respondents/Defendants.  § 
 
 
BRIEF IN SUPPORT OF DEFENDANT’S MOTION TO DISMISS 
 
 
Plaintiffs, all of whom are, or were, state detainees at the Dallas County Jail, challenge 
their conditions of confinement under the auspices of a Section 2241 habeas claim. The Fifth 
Circuit has held that habeas relief is not an appropriate vehicle to challenge conditions of 
confinement. As such, Plaintiffs have failed to state a claim for which relief can be granted, and 
their habeas claims should be dismissed. FED. R. CIV. P. 12(b)(6). 
Plaintiffs’ habeas claims should also be dismissed because they have failed to exhaust 
their remedies in state court, and have not provided any basis on which one can reasonably 
conclude that Plaintiffs are excused from exhausting their state law remedies. Id. 
Finally, the post-adjudication Plaintiffs may not use § 1983 to seek release because doing 
so would undermine the validity of their convictions. Those claims should also be dismissed. Id. 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554444
 
I.  Standard of Review 
To survive a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, a plaintiff must 
plead “enough facts to state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.” Bell Atl. Corp. v. 
Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 (2007). A claim is facially plausible when the plaintiff pleads 
factual content that allows the court to draw a reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for 
the misconduct alleged. Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009). Assuming they are true, a 
plaintiff’s allegations must be enough to raise a right to relief above the speculative level. 
Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555. 
II.  Plaintiffs’ habeas claims must be dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) because they have 
not exhausted available state court remedies. 
In order to be eligible for habeas relief a petitioner must have exhausted his or her 
available state remedies. Dickerson v. Louisiana, 816 F.2d 220, 224 (5th Cir. 1987).  The 
common law exhaustion doctrine imposed on Section 2241(c)(3) was crafted based on concerns 
about the delicate state–federal balance in order to protect state courts’ opportunity to confront 
and resolve initially any constitutional issues arising within their jurisdictions as well as to limit 
federal interference in the state adjudicatory process. Braden v. 30th Judicial Circuit Court of 
Ky., 410 U.S. 484, 489–92 (1973).  
Texas law provides for the reduction of bail and release thereon. TEX. CODE CRIM. P. art. 
17.09 § 3. The Texas Code of Criminal Procedure provides factors that guide judicial discretion 
in  setting  bond  amounts.  Id.  art.  17.15.  Texas  procedure also  affords  clear  timeframes  for 
mandatory bond reduction or imposition of a personal bond. Id. art. 17.151. Habeas relief is also 
available under Texas law. See, e.g., In re McCray, 324 S.W.3d 685 (Tex. App.—Dallas 2010, 
orig. proceeding). 
2 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554455
 
Plaintiffs  do  not  allege  that  they  have  exhausted  their  state  law  remedies.  In  fact, 
Plaintiffs do not allege that any one of them has sought any state law remedy. Instead, they 
allege that “Section 2241 contains no exhaustion requirement conceivably applicable to prisoners 
seeking  COVID-based  discharge.”  ECF  No.  1  at  38  ¶  86.  Plaintiffs’  claim  ignores  the 
longstanding principle that, as a matter of comity, federal courts do not ignore available state 
adjudicatory processes. 
The only exception to the exhaustion requirement that Plaintiffs cite is the exception for 
when state procedures do not afford swift vindication. Id. The pre-adjudication Plaintiffs do not 
contend that they sought expedited bond review hearings or initiated any state court remedy. The 
post-adjudication plaintiffs likewise do not allege that they initiated any state court proceedings 
to  seek  release.  They  merely  say  that  these  processes  “would  take  months  under  normal 
circumstances, and certainly will now take longer.” Id. Plaintiffs’ argument fails for four reasons. 
First, Plaintiffs pretend, without evidence, that they would lose at every stage of the 
habeas  process  and  be  forced  to  pursue  appeals.  Second,  while  Plaintiffs  ignore  the  bond 
reduction  process,  they  attach  an  e-mail  from  the  Dallas  County  Criminal  District  Courts 
Manager, Keta Dickerson. ECF No. 1-11 at 4. Ms. Dickerson informed court-appointed counsel 
that the Criminal District Courts are: 
  Currently open; 
  Conducting essential hearings by any and all available means; 
  Prioritizing bail hearings and jail pleas; 
  Taking all reasonable steps to avoid exposing people to the threat of 
coronavirus; and 
  Working to try to streamline an electronic system for hearing bond matters 
and jail pleas. 
3 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  44  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554466
 
ECF No. 1-11 at 4. This evidence does not support a contention that available state law remedies, 
such as bond reduction or personal bonds, are futile or will take months; it supports a finding that 
state courts are “prioritizing bail hearings and jail pleas” and “taking all reasonable steps to avoid 
exposing people to the threat of coronavirus.” Id.  
Third, Plaintiffs’ attempt to escape their obligation to seek adequate state law remedies 
fails because their conclusory allegation that COVID-19 will lengthen the time it takes for them 
to obtain relief in state courts. ECF No. 1 at 38 ¶ 86 & n.103. What Plaintiffs fail to mention is 
that the only Dallas County courts that are closed are municipal courts.1 Municipal courts do not 
have jurisdiction over offenses that may result in incarceration. TEX. GOV’T CODE § 29.003. 
Finally, available state law remedies have been anything but futile or slow in the last 
month. Plaintiffs rely on the Dallas County Jail’s daily population report data for April 6, 2020. 
ECF No. 1 at 30 ¶ 71.  
The Supreme Court of Texas and the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals jointly issued 
their first order regarding court operations during COVID-19 on March 13, 2020. Misc. Order 
No. 20-9042 (Tex. Mar. 13, 2020); Misc. Order No. 20-007 (Tex. Crim. App. Mar. 13, 2020).2 
The daily population report to which Plaintiffs refer shows a steep decline in Dallas County Jail 
population since March 13, 2020. On March 15, 2020, the total Jail population was 5,952. The 
population declined to 5,618 on March 24, and again to 5,225 on April 3, and finally to 5,180 on 
April 6. Today’s Jail population is under 5,000.3 
                                                 
1 Current & Upcoming Closures, Texas Judicial Branch, https://www.txcourts.gov/ 
programs-services/court-security/emergency-court-preparedness/closures/ (last visited Apr. 15, 
2020). 
2 Available at https://www.txcourts.gov/media/coronavirus-covid-19-emergency-orders/. 
3 Courts may routinely consider not just documents named in Plaintiffs’ Complaint, but 
also documents that, if not named, are pertinent, central, or integral to Plaintiffs’ claim. Bryant v. 
Avado Brands, 187 F.3d 1271, 1281 (11th Cir. 1999). Documents relied on by a defendant are 
4 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  55  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554477
 
Plaintiffs’ Complaint acknowledges that detainees have been released recently. ECF No. 
1 at 26 ¶ 61. The data to which Plaintiffs refer, however, demonstrates just how diligently the 
Dallas County Criminal Court at Law and State District Court judges have been working to 
release detainees when possible.4 
Dallas County Jail Population
6200
6000
5800
5600
5400
5200
5000
4800
9‐Feb 19‐Feb 29‐Feb 10‐Mar 20‐Mar 30‐Mar 9‐Apr 19‐Apr
 
There is no support for Plaintiffs’ conclusory allegation that state law remedies have been 
slow or unavailable. At a minimum, it is incongruous for Plaintiffs to allege that state procedures 
do not afford swift vindication; attach evidence that Dallas County courts are open, using all 
available means to conduct essential hearings, and prioritizing bail hearings and jail pleas; and 
not allege or show that any plaintiff has sought any relief in state court. There is no reason to 
depart from the well-established rule that habeas plaintiffs must exhaust state court remedies 
before seeking relief in federal court. Plaintiffs’ habeas claims should be dismissed. 
                                                                                                                                                             
considered part of the pleadings if they are referred to in the plaintiffs’ complaint and are central 
to plaintiffs’ claims. Collins v. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, 224 F.3d 496, 498–99 (5th Cir. 
2000). 
4 For context, Defendants refer to the remainder of the relevant public reports to which 
Plaintiffs refer. Those reports are attached as Exhibit 1. 
5 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  66  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554488
 
III.  Plaintiffs  have  not  stated  a  claim  for  habeas  relief  because  their  claims  raise 
questions unrelated to the myriad causes of their detention. 
Habeas is not available to review questions unrelated to the cause of detention. The “sole 
function” of a writ of habeas corpus is to grant relief from unlawful imprisonment or custody and 
it cannot be used properly for any other purpose.” Pierre v. United States, 525 F.2d 933, 935–36 
(5th Cir. 1976). Plaintiffs complain about their conditions of confinement, not the cause for their 
detention.  Plaintiffs  do  not  allege  that  any  order  of  confinement  was  procured  or  issued 
improperly. Plaintiffs do not allege that their convictions and the judgments thereon were entered 
in violation of their constitutional rights. Instead, they say the conditions of their confinement 
require release. Whatever their conditions of confinement, they are not related to Plaintiffs’ 
“cause of detention.” As such, Plaintiffs’ Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus must fail, and the 
Court should dismiss those claims pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6). 
Plaintiffs attempt to distinguish Pierre—which remains binding precedent—by saying 
that it is not clear how Section 2241 would apply in the context of COVID-19. This argument 
fails.  “Allegations  that  challenge  rules,  customs,  and  procedures  affecting  conditions  of 
confinement are properly brought in civil rights actions.” Schipke v. Van Buren, 239 Fed. App’x 
85, 85–76 (5th Cir. 2007).  Even when a habeas petitioner alleges that inadequate conditions of 
confinement create the risk of serious physical injury, illness, or death, a petition for a writ of 
habeas corpus is not the proper vehicle for such a claim. See, e.g., Spencer v. Bragg, 310 Fed. 
App’x 678, 679 (5th Cir. 2009) (affirming the lower court’s dismissal of petitioner’s habeas 
claim even though he alleged that the conditions of confinement endangered his life). A petition 
for habeas corpus may not be used as a vehicle to challenge conditions of confinement. As such, 
Plaintiffs  have  not  pleaded,  and  cannot  plead,  any  set  of  facts  under  which  they  could 
6 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  77  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  554499
 
conceivably obtain habeas relief. Their habeas claims should be dismissed. FED. R. CIV. P. 
12(b)(6). 
IV.  The post-adjudication Plaintiffs fail to state a § 1983 claim because they challenge 
the fact of their confinement and seek immediate release. 
Plaintiffs’ Complaint makes no effort to hide what they seek: “immediate release is the 
only  medically  and  legally  sound  remedy,  rather  than  mere  mitigation  and/or  further 
proceedings.” ECF No. 1 at 37 ¶ 85. “Plaintiffs . . request immediate release of all Plaintiffs and 
Class Members.” Id. at 4 ¶ 9. 
A prisoner in state custody cannot use a § 1983 action to challenge the fact or duration of 
confinement and seek immediate release. Preiser v. Rodriguez, 411 U.S. 475, 489 (1973). He or 
she must seek federal habeas corpus relief or appropriate state relief instead. Id.  When a 
prisoner’s action demands immediate release or a shorter period of detention, it lies at the core of 
habeas corpus, and the prisoner may not pursue relief under § 1983. Id. 
Under Preiser, the post-adjudication Plaintiffs may not seek release under § 1983. When 
they are not seeking relief contrary to Preiser or ancillary relief predicated on release, the post-
adjudication Plaintiffs’ prayer seeks to alter the terms of their valid convictions and sentences. 
See, e.g., ECF. No. 1 at 42–43 ¶¶ 2, 5(a), 5(d). This relief is unavailable because it would 
necessarily imply the invalidity of their convictions and sentences. Heck v. Humphrey, 512 U.S. 
477 (1994). Plaintiffs ask this Court to impose additional restrictions on the validity of state court 
judgments ordering Plaintiffs to serve terms of confinement. According to Plaintiffs, they may 
not be sentenced to a term of confinement absent judicially recorded findings by clear and 
convincing evidence that the individual poses a danger to others that no condition other than 
confinement can mitigate. See, e.g., ECF No. 1 at 42–43 ¶¶ 2, 5(a), 5(d). Plaintiffs cite no 
authority that this requirement arises from the Constitution, or that such a requirement can be 
7 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  88  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  555500
 
retroactively applied to invalidate state court judgments. There is none.5 Because they seek 
release or additional findings to support their state court judgments, which would necessarily 
invalidate those judgments, the post-adjudication Plaintiffs have failed to state a § 1983 claim. 
V.  The Court should abstain from entertaining Plaintiffs’ claims. 
In a memorandum opinion issued yesterday, Judge Rosenthal explained the prudential 
reasons for a federal court to abstain from wading into the fracas to interfere with ongoing state 
efforts to respond to dynamic conditions. ECF No. 31. Abstention is particularly warranted 
where Plaintiffs seek to deploy the blunt instrument of constitutional litigation to obtain crude 
court-fashioned remedies that carry the threat of contempt. Id.; see Benzman v. Whitman, 523 
F.3d 119, 125 (2d Cir. 2008). Abstention is also counseled by the strong policy that federal 
courts should not intervene in pending state court proceedings, such as those in which the pre-
adjudication Plaintiffs are involved. Younger v. Harris, 401 U.S. 37 (1971); Middlesex Cnty. 
Ethics. Comm’n v. Garden State Bar Ass’n, 457 U.S. 423, 431 (1983). 
If the Court does not dismiss all of Plaintiffs’ claims, the Court should nevertheless 
abstain from intervening at this juncture in order to allow state officials to weigh the competing 
interests at play in managing the Dallas County jail during this COVID-19 outbreak. 
CONCLUSION AND PRAYER 
Under binding Fifth Circuit precedent, Plaintiffs’ cannot use habeas claims to challenge 
their conditions of confinement. As such, Plaintiffs’ habeas claims should be dismissed under 
Rule 12(b)(6). Further, Plaintiffs do not allege that they have attempted to access state law 
remedies, much less exhaust them. Federal courts do not entertain state prisoners’ habeas claims 
unless those petitioners first exhaust state court remedies. In light of the available state court 
                                                 
5 See also Daves v. Dallas Cnty., Tex., 341 F. Supp. 3d 688, 695–96 (N.D. Tex. 2018). 
8 
 
DocID: 4847-0616-8762.2

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  3366      FFiilleedd  0044//1155//2200        PPaaggee  99  ooff  1100      PPaaggeeIIDD  555511
 
remedies, and the fact that Plaintiffs’ own evidence demonstrates the efficacy of those remedies, 
there is no good reason for the Court to excuse Plaintiffs from the exhaustion requirement. Their 
failure to exhaust is an additional and independent reason for which Plaintiffs’ habeas claims 
should be dismissed. 
Not only can Plaintiffs not use habeas as a vehicle to challenge the conditions of their 
confinement, the post-adjudication Plaintiffs may not use § 1983 to collaterally attack their 
conviction or seek relief. Because the post-adjudication Plaintiffs’ § 1983 claim seeks release, 
those claims should be dismissed under Rule 12(b)(6) as well. 
Regarding the remaining claims—the pre-adjudication § 1983 claims—the Court should 
abstain from ruling on the basis of Younger. 
Defendants also pray for all other and further relief to which they are justly entitled. 
Date:  April 15, 2020         Respectfully Submitted, 
HUSCH BLACKWELL LLP

documents.title: Order
documents.text:
CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  11  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11554499
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
DALLAS DIVISION 
 
OSCAR SANCHEZ, et al., on their own  § 
and on behalf of a class  § 
of others similarly situated,  § 
    § 
  Plaintiffs/Petitioners,  § 
    § 
v.    §  CIVIL ACTION NO. 3:20-cv-00832-E 
    § 
DALLAS COUNTY SHERIFF   § 
MARIAN BROWN, in her official capacity,  §  
and DALLAS COUNTY, TEXAS,  § 
    § 
  Defendants/Respondents.  § 
 
ORDER 
Plaintiffs, detainees in the Dallas County Jail, filed a First Amended Petition for Writ of 
Habeas Corpus and Class Action Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief [Doc. No. 39]. 
Due to COVID-19 at the jail, Plaintiffs seek relief that includes the immediate release of medically 
vulnerable subclass members.  The State of Texas, the Governor of Texas, and the Attorney 
General of Texas (“Proposed Intervenors”) have filed a Motion to Intervene as defendants in this 
case [Doc. No. 26] (“the Motion”).   Existing Defendants Dallas County, Texas, and the Dallas 
County Sheriff do not oppose the Motion, but Plaintiffs do [Doc. No. 44].  Proposed Intervenors 
assert they are entitled to intervene by right under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(a)(2) and 
also to permissive intervention under Rule 24(b)(1)(B). For the reasons that follow, the Court 
grants the Motion.  
I.  Introduction 
  Some of the named Plaintiffs are pretrial detainees.   The Court is mindful the Due Process 
Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution presumes each individual innocent 
1 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  22  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555500
if, and until, she is convicted of the crime for which she stands accused. But that presumption is 
not applicable when analyzing the issue of pretrial confinement. In Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520 
(1979), the Supreme Court considered federal pretrial detainees’ class action suit against a New 
York City jail where the inmates were housed in which plaintiffs alleged the conditions of the jail 
violated their statutory and constitutional rights. In Bell, the Supreme Court made the following 
clear: 
The presumption of innocence is a doctrine that allocates the burden of proof in 
criminal trials; it also may serve as an admonishment to the jury to judge an 
accused’s guilt or innocence solely on the evidence adduced at trial. . . . Without 
question, the presumption of innocence plays an important role in our criminal 
justice system. “The principle that there is a presumption of innocence in favor of 
the accused is the undoubted law, axiomatic and elementary, and its enforcement 
lies at the foundation of the administration of our criminal law.”  Coffin v. United 
States, 156 U.S. 432, 453, 15 S.Ct. 394, 403, 39 L.Ed. 481 (1895). But it has no 
application to a determination of the rights of a pretrial detainee during confinement 
before his trial has even begun. 
 
Bell, 441 U.S. at 533.  
  In a humane society, even those convicted of the most serious crimes, if they must be 
confined, should be held as safely as possible. Society should also provide jailed persons with 
appropriate medical care if an inmate becomes ill. 
II.  Intervention by Right  
  Proposed Intervenors contend Plaintiffs want “to empty the jail” and seek to intervene to 
defend the continued custody of the would-be class.  They contend they have an interest in the 
outcome of this case and in protecting the public’s health and safety “in the wake of the coronavirus 
pandemic.”  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 24(a)(2) allows the Proposed Intervenors to intervene 
as a matter of right if they can show:  1) the timeliness of the motion to intervene; 2) an interest 
relating to the action; 3) disposition of the case may impair or impede their ability to protect the 
interest; and 4) the interest is not adequately represented by the existing parties. See FED. R. CIV. 
2 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  33  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555511
P. 24(a)(2); Adam Joseph Res. v. CNA Metals Ltd., 919 F.3d 856, 865 (5th Cir. 2019).  Courts 
should construe Rule 24(a) broadly in favor of intervenors.  See Adam Joseph, 919 F.3d at 864.  
Generally, intervention should be allowed when no one would be hurt and when greater justice 
can be attained by allowing the intervention.   Doe #1 v. Glickman, 256 F.3d 371, 375 (5th Cir. 
2001).  
  In Plaintiffs’ response to the Motion, they assert that Proposed Intervenors “have at best a 
contingent interest in a small number of post-conviction detainees who may belong in State 
custody.”  Plaintiffs also warn the Court of what they view as fearmongering by Proposed 
Intervenors:   
[Proposed Intervenors] list a parade of horribles, led by an accused serial killer, to 
attempt to persuade the Court that nothing short of their intervention in this lawsuit 
will save the State of Texas from the harm of releasing every accused and convicted 
murderer, rapist, burglar, batterer, fraudster and other criminal from the Dallas 
County Jail – over 5,000 prisoners in total. . . . Tellingly, [Proposed Intervenors] 
fail to note that Plaintiffs do not seek such indiscriminate relief in their Complaint. 
 
Plaintiffs contest Proposed Intervenors’ claim that Plaintiffs seek to “empty the jail.”   Yet 
Plaintiffs’ First Amended Petition for Habeas Corpus and Class Action Complaint requests not 
only that this Court immediately release medically vulnerable subclass members, but also that the 
Court continue to release, via habeas or transfer to home confinement, additional class members, 
including those not considered medically vulnerable, as needed to ensure that persons who remain 
incarcerated do so under conditions consistent with public health guidelines.  And Plaintiffs’ 
Motion for Class Certification [Doc. No. 17], contemplates a “Pre-Adjudication Class” which 
includes all current and future detainees in pretrial custody at the jail and a “Post-Adjudication 
Class”  which  includes  all  current  and  future  detainees  in  post-adjudication  custody,  with 
subclasses for those who are medically vulnerable. 
3 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  44  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555522
  The Court finds that Proposed Intervenors have met the requirements for an intervention 
by right.  First, Proposed Intervenors’ Motion was timely. Plaintiffs filed their original Petition for 
Writ of Habeas Corpus and Class Action Complaint and their Motion for Temporary Restraining 
Order, Preliminary Injunction, and Writ of Habeas Corpus and accompanying brief [Doc. Nos. 1–
3] on April 9, 2020. Proposed Intervenors filed their Motion just 4 days later. No discovery had 
taken place before Proposed Intervenors filed their Motion.   
The focus of the second prong is practical. See Adam Joseph, 919 F.3d at 867. Considering 
the broad relief sought by Plaintiffs, the Court sees a direct, substantial, and legally protectable 
interest relating to this action held by Proposed Intervenors in the proceedings and outcome of this 
case. See In re Lease Oil Antitrust Litig., 570 F.3d 244, 250 (5th Cir. 2009). If the Court grants 
Plaintiffs’ requested relief, the State itself, the Governor as the State’s executive head, and the 
Attorney General as the State’s legal counsel, may be affected in other cases in which they are 
parties. Plaintiffs seek release of up to nearly 5,000 inmates from the Dallas County Jail due to 
coronavirus (COVID-19) concerns.  The broad relief requested supports Proposed Intervenors’ 
argument that they have a vested interest, especially during a pandemic, in keeping citizens safe 
and not draining the law enforcement resources currently available.  See Addington v. Tex., 441 
U.S. 418, 426 (1979) (discussing concept of State’s parens patriae interest in caring for citizens); 
City of Safety Harbor v. Birchfield, 529 F.2d 1251, 1256 n. 7 (5th Cir. 1976) (same).  And as an 
example of other potential concerns, the release Plaintiffs seek could mean setting aside active 
parole warrants from the Texas Department of Criminal Justice. See TEX. GOV’T CODE ANN. 
§ 508.254.    
Plaintiffs claim Proposed Intervenors have only a de minimus interest in the issues before 
the Court, but Plaintiffs wholly fail to address Proposed Intervenors’ asserted interest in crime 
4 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  55  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555533
prevention. [See Doc. No. 27 exhibits Nos. 1-15.]  A mass exodus of inmates from the Dallas 
County Jail would likely impact citizens outside Dallas County. Exhibit 13 to the Motion is a 
declaration from City of Plano Police Chief Ed Drain. This declaration was originally filed in 
response to a similar lawsuit filed in the Southern District of Texas seeking to release inmates from 
the Harris County Jail. See Russell v. Harris Cty., No. 4:19-cv-00226 (S.D. Tex). Chief Drain 
wrote, “[i]t is my understanding that the Plaintiffs in this lawsuit are seeking an order releasing 
over 4,000 felons from the Harris County Jail.” Chief Drain explained the strain such a mass 
release would have on law enforcement during a pandemic and some of the intrastate consequences 
of releasing 4,000 inmates: 
Organized criminal elements form [sic] the Harris County area are frequently 
engaged in illegal activity in other jurisdictions hundreds of miles from Harris 
County. For approximately the last ten years, numerous Asians residents [sic] in 
the City of Plano, have been victimized by an organized criminal element who 
specialize in burglarizing homes of Asians. In cases where we have been able to 
arrest suspects involved in these crimes, we usually can trace their origins to the 
Harris County area. 
 
Chief Drain, who has been a law enforcement officer for over 25 years, expressed just how often 
criminal activity crossed county lines: 
Over approximately the last five years, we have seen an increase in criminal activity 
that involves criminals identifying bank customers who have made large cash 
withdrawals. The criminals follow the victim’s vehicle and steal the cash whenever 
the customer makes a stop. The criminal activity is referred to as “jugging”.  We 
consistently discover suspects we arrest for these offenses are from the Harris 
County area. 
 
These intrastate crime concerns were not just a problem Chief Drain faced as a police officer in 
Plano.  During the time he served as the Police Chief in Amarillo, “almost all suspects we arrested 
involved in placing skimmers on gas pumps to steal victims’ credit/debit card information, were 
from the Harris County area.”  Though Chief Drain’s declaration and the other fourteen exhibits 
attached to the Motion focused on the possible release of inmates from the Harris County Jail, 
5 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  66  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555544
Proposed Intervenors’ concerns are as applicable to Dallas County and its jail as they are to the 
State of Texas.  
Proposed Intervenors have also established the third requirement for intervention by right.  
The relief requested by Plaintiffs creates a tangible threat to  Proposed Intervenors’  legally 
cognizable interests, which would likely be impaired or impeded by this case if the Court barred 
Proposed Intervenors’ participation in this suit or if there were an unfavorable result for Proposed 
Intervenors in this case. See Pennsylvania v. President United States of Am., 888 F.3d 52, 59 (3d 
Cir. 2018); Mountain Top Condo. Ass’n v. Dave Stabbert Master Builder, Inc., 72 F.3d 361, 366 
(3d Cir. 1995). Proposed Intervenors have also shown an interest in this suit that is direct, 
substantial, and legally protectable. See Brumfield v. Dodd, 749 F.3d 339, 343 (5th Cir. 2014). 
Further, Proposed Intervenors’ stake in this suit goes beyond a generalized preference that the case 
turn out a certain way. See Texas v. U.S., 805 F.3d 653, 657 (5th Cir. 2015).   
  The last prong focuses on whether the existing parties adequately represent the Proposed 
Intervenors’ interests. The burden to prove that they do not is not a substantial one. Brumfield, 749 
F.3d at 345. Proposed Intervenors need only show that the existing representation “may be 
inadequate.” Texas, 805 F.3d at 661 (quoting Trbovich v. United Mine Workers of Am., 404 U.S. 
528, 538 n.10 (1972)); Doe #1, 256 F.3d at 380 (same).  
  Motions and briefs filed by Defendants have focused primarily on the effects Plaintiffs’ 
requested relief would have for Dallas County and its jail. Proposed Intervenors’ stated reason for 
filing the Motion was to “ensur[e] that Texas’s interests are zealously represented before the Court 
by the elected officials entrusted with defending the state’s interests.” Proposed Intervenors’ 
Motion raises valid concerns that existing representation may be inadequate to represent Proposed 
Intervenor’s interests.  
6 
 

CCaassee  33::2200--ccvv--0000883322--EE      DDooccuummeenntt  7700      FFiilleedd  0044//2200//2200        PPaaggee  77  ooff  77      PPaaggeeIIDD  11555555
III.  Conclusion   
  Because  Proposed  Intervenors  have  met  the  requirements  of  Federal  Rule  of  Civil 
Procedure 24(a)(2), the Court finds intervention by right is appropriate.  Accordingly, the Court 
need not consider Proposed Intervenors’ alternative argument that they are entitled to permissive 
intervention under Rule 24(b).  See, e.g., Securities & Exch. Comm’n v. Sethi Petroleum LLC, No. 
4:15-CV-00338, 2020 WL 363777, at *8 (E.D. Tex. Jan. 22, 2020).  Proposed Intervenors’ Motion 
to Intervene is granted.   
SO ORDERED. 
Signed April 20, 2020 
 
                 
              JUDGE ADA BROWN 
              UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
              NORTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
 
7

UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF TEXAS 
DALLAS DIVISION 
 
OSCAR SANCHEZ, MARCUS  § 
WHITE, TESMOND MCDONALD,  § 
MARCELO PEREZ, ROGER  § 
MORRISON, KEITH BAKER, PAUL  § 
WRIGHT, TERRY MCNICKELS, and  § 
JOSE MUNOZ, on their own and on  § 
behalf of a class of similarly situated  § 
persons,  § 
  Plaintiffs/Petitioners,  § 
 
  § 
Case No. 3:20-cv-00832-E 
v.  § 
  § 
DALLAS COUNTY SHERIFF,  § 
MARIAN BROWN, in her official  § 
capacity; DALLAS COUNTY, TEXAS;  § 
STATE OF TEXAS; GOVERNOR OF  § 
TEXAS; and ATTORNEY GENERAL  § 
OF TEXAS,  § 
  Defendants/Respondents.   § 
 
 
 
Notice of Supplemental Authority 
 
 
We write to alert this Court to the Fifth Circuit’s decision from yesterday in 
Marlowe v. LeBlanc, — F.3d —, No. 20-30276 (5th Cir. Apr. 27, 2020) (slip opinion 
attached).  While  this  Court  has  already  denied  Plaintiffs’  requested  relief  (and 
Marlowe does not change that result), State Intervenors bring this binding authority 
to  this  Court’s  attention  because  it  forecloses  several  of  Plaintiffs’  attempts  to 
distinguish Valentine v. Collier; therefore, providing further support for the Court’s 
forthcoming written opinion. 
1

Respectfully submitted. 
 
KEN PAXTON

DARREN L. MCCARTY
